utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, but I think --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Nuclear power, Scott Adams, opioids are great, animals are great, animals and opioids apparently.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But see now, see, he has the power of persuasion, I think in his mind because he thinks now everybody knows animals are great. They get it in their head, they associate it with him. But remember in Nashville, the other thing he did?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Just to talk about Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Watters -- fine.

utterances.sentences: There we are. Up next, a presidential candidate enters “Watters' World.” It's not Joe Biden. Someone else, we will show you.

utterances.sentences: Are you serious?

utterances.sentences: Well, thank you for joining me. Although, we go a long way back.

utterances.sentences: Who did you see?

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.sentences: Mr. Joe Biden. They have him working for the TSA.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: If that's right -- in his wheelhouse.

utterances.sentences: Yes. Unfortunately, he fell asleep while he was sniffing my wife's hair.

utterances.sentences: I'm telling you.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir. Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.sentences: It is called Pony Up, America.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, so people donate to you. And then you use that money to travel around.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.sentences: The more I can convince people to give me money, verminsupreme.com, the more I can spend, and yes, I've been traveling around the country to appear at various libertarian conventions.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And it's a beautiful country, is it not?

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.sentences: It truly is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, so here's why --

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.sentences: And it must only be spent on legitimate campaign expenses.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right. Like your boot?

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.sentences: Yes. That's would be a legitimate campaign expense.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's a legitimate campaign expense.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.sentences: If I were to buy a pony, that would be a legitimate campaign.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay, good.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.sentences: Yes, it would be.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So I have my opinion that there's so many Democrats running for President because a lot of them just like want to do what you do is raise a lot of money, travel the country in the warm weather, raise their speaking fees, maybe write a book and network around and then when it gets cold, they'll just drop right out.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.sentences: Absolutely, sir. I mean, many people run for many different reasons. And of course, selling books and upping your speaking fee and gaining national notoriety is certainly one of those things that people do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And I don't see your platform is that different than a lot of the other candidates. I mean, you had people trimming their nose hairs. You have people like what? Working out at the gym and they're doing all this crazy stuff. I mean, you and the rest of the Democratic field, there's not that big of a difference.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.sentences: Oh yes. I've got a preview of a regular guy and you do regular things all the time. I'm just a regular guy doing regular things. I got a haircut once. Look at that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.sentences: Yes, sure.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You actually need a little beard trim. You should go in there and like livestream that or something like that.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.sentences: I think we will.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: People might like that.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.sentences: Well, Beto did that teeth cleaning stunt, obviously referencing to the mandatory tooth brushing law.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, you don't like stunts at all?

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.sentences: Oh, no, no, because gingivitis has been eroding the gum line of this great nation of ours for long enough and must be stopped. For too long, our country has been suffering a great moral and oral decay in spirit and incisors. Our country's future depends on its ability to bite back. We can no longer be a nation indentured. We must brace ourselves, our very salvation is at stake as we cross the bridge work into the 23rd Century, may we become a sea of shining smiles from sea to shining smiles.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Good luck in 2020.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Don't forget, Vermin Supreme, my new book, "I Pony." My new book.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Up next, "Last Call."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Time now for "Last Call." The NBA Draft this week and the New York Knicks missed out on the number one overall pick, Zion Williamson leaving fans like Stephen A. Smith, really upset.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE

I cannot believe this. I can't take it. I love you all, but I've got to go. I'm just too offended.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: Well, I can't pronounce his name either.

utterances.speaker: HUCKABEE
utterances.utterance: Well, the thing that you've got to love about the President, he is so good, but he brands people so beautifully. And once it is stuck. I mean, you know, all I can say is McDonald's is the only brand I know that sticks better than the things that Donald Trump puts on somebody because once they're on, it's on like Super Glue.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, even when he said Crazy Bernie all the way down there in Louisiana, Herman. The crowd was just eating it up.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: Yes. They were eating it up. Here's the one thing that all of the 23 Democratic presidential wannabes have in common, and I believe that the President has observed it and that is, they all have at least one socialist idea that they are trying to separate themselves from the other candidates on. And one of the ones that I know we're going to talk about Beto O'Rourke. He even made the statement in front of a crowd that the Tax Code needs to be used to give more money to black people. That's an insult. It is divisive and it is ridiculous. I had someone ask me the other day, "What has President Trump done for black people?" I said, "All you have to do is look at what he has done for all people and this nation and black people have also benefited." Beto and others are trying to divide us on these socialist ideas that's part of the socialist creep that's trying to come into our culture.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, well, it's going to be capitalism versus socialism in 2020. I think I know how it's going to go, just knowing the country, but I guess we have to let the voters decide.

utterances.speaker: CAIN
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We didn't have enough time to get to Beto's ear hair trimming. So guys, just you know, keep your powder dry. Maybe we'll get to that next week. All right, Governor, Herman, good to see you.

utterances.speaker: HUCKABEE
utterances.utterance: Hey, Jesse, let's just pray he doesn't have a scare in -- I hope he doesn't have a colonoscopy. He will want to put that on livestream as well.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, drop out before you go to get that done, please, Beto, please. All right, guys. Up next to the great one, Mark Levin is going to be in “Watters' World,” and later, classic movies that wouldn't survive in today's PC World. We'll take a look.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAM BARR, ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.utterance: I think spying on a political campaign is a big deal. I think spying did occur. But the question is whether it was predicated -- adequately predicated, and I am not suggesting it wasn't adequately predicated, but I need to explore that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Attorney General Bill Barr making good on his word, appointing top Federal prosecutor, John Durham to dig into the origins of the Russia collusion hoax and to determine if spying on the Trump campaign was politically motivated. This has totally boomeranged on the Deep State and the main players are starting to turn against each other now that the heat is turned up. The Obama State Department blaming the FBI. Brennan blaming Comey and Comey and Rosenstein are apparently trading blows. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: JAMES COMEY, FORMER FBI DIRECTOR
utterances.utterance: I think people like that, like Rod Rosenstein, who are people of accomplishment but not real Sterling character, strong character.

utterances.speaker: ROD ROSENSTEIN, FORMER DEPUTY ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.utterance: Now the former Director seems to be acting as a partisan pundit selling books, and earning speaking fees while speculating about the strength of my character.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Here with reaction, the host of "Life, Liberty & Levin," the great one and the author of the upcoming book, "Unfreedom of the Press," Mark Levin and we're going to get to the book in a second. But Mark, this reminds me of you know, when you're outside in the backyard, and you pull a rock up, and all the little bugs start scurrying around and looking for cover and start fighting each other. This is what's happening.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: You know, Comey really is a reprobate though. I mean, when it comes to the worst of the worst, he is the worst of the worst. You remember when he was fired by the President? Remember the Democrats? One of them fired until Trump actually fired him. He said, "You know, it's the President, he can do whatever you wants." Now, we know he leaked, and he was a coward when he leaked. He leaked through a law Professor because he didn't want to get caught, but he got caught. All this going on at the FBI was taking place when he was director of the FBI. He is fighting with his former Deputy Director of the FBI. He says these outrageous things about the President of the United States. He is a real reprobate. And really, it goes back to President Obama. Obama, with Comey. Obama with Brennan. Obama with Clapper. The Three Stooges of Intelligence and law enforcement -- a disaster. You know, I was Chief of Staff to an Attorney General. We had serious people in these positions. And they never would leave their positions, retire and then go on cable TV or anywhere else and start attacking the opposition party. You never heard from them again. Maybe they'd write a book, maybe they'd join a think tank. These guys go over to MSNBC and CNN and these these phony seminars or wherever they're going on, going on and on. I mean, Jim Comey, seriously, the Russians were interfering with our election. Jim Comey was the Director of the FBI, what the hell do they do about it? As far as I know, nothing effective, that's for sure.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Now, so usually conservatives get their hopes up when we think things are turning around. That's happened many times. You know, it's always the case where, you know, this is just about to happen, and it doesn't, or you know, Hillary is about to get indicted and it doesn't happen. Is this going to be one of those times, again, where you appoint a prosecutor, Durham, great reputation, but it turns out, no one gets punished.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: You know, I never get my hopes up. I just plow ahead. And that's what we ought to do. I don't know this prosecutor in Connecticut. Everybody says he is great. I never heard of him before yesterday. You know, back in 1961, there was a gentleman by the name of Daniel Borstein. He became the head of the Library Congress, and he wrote a book. And he used to call these things, "pseudo events." So the President viscerally is right. And he says, when you look at the media, it's filled with pseudo events. Collusion for two years was a pseudo event. Obstruction, so-called built from -- is another pseudo event. Seven hundred prosecutors, former prosecutors write a letter, there's tens of thousands of former prosecutors. So these are all liberals who hate Trump, another pseudo event. Some guy writes an op-ed in the "New York Times," anonymous -- pseudo event. And we spend days and weeks talking about non-news, and then it's filled with propaganda where they go, "Look we're connecting the dots of pseudo events." And now we're talking about all these subpoenas and constitutional crisis, more pseudo phony events,

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, and the real events like the border crisis, they don't cover. Look at this book I have here. Mark Levin, "Unfreedom of the Press." Now --

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: It's beautiful.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean, I cannot wait to dig my teeth into this thing. This thing is coming out and May 21st, Tuesday.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Correct. Correct.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't know. Jim Acosta has got a book out. He says it's a dangerous time to tell the truth in America. I don't know. Acosta-Levin? How is it going to play out in the "New York Times" list?

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Well, first of all, I didn't know Jim Acosta could read, let alone write. But that's okay. He is in my book, too, because he is a complete fraud. And his dramatic activities at the White House are intended to provide substance for his book. It's really an outrage. But you raise a very good point. What is "Unfreedom of the Press" about? We have a media and then we have free press and the Constitution. They are two different things right now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: That which is undermining the free press is the modern mass media. And they're undermining the free press in several ways. And this is very, very important. Number one, they've decided to throw in one political party. You know, back in the 1800s, we had a party press -- media would side with one party or another. Now they side with one party. We know this from surveys and polls that go back decades.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Ideologically, they are progressive. There's simply no question about it. Again, we know from surveys and polls that they are liberal, for the most part. What else do we know? Now we know that they've turned the corner. They're not interested in pursuing objective news, they say they will. And if you criticize them, they immediately say, "Oh, you're attacking freedom of the press."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: They are social activists. That's what they've become. You can't see a dime's worth a difference between most newsrooms in this country and most journalists in this country, and the Democratic Party, which is why they're so comfortable bringing Schiff on and Nadler on, they all sound alike, they all act alike. Now, Jesse, this isn't new, but it's gotten much worse. In 1942, there was a report by the media about the media, by the way, the media today is not circumspect, you'd never see a report by the media about the media today. And one of the things they said back then was the greatest danger and fear should be the mixture of news with opinion. You know, we at Fox, we try to separate the two.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: You're not a news guy. I'm not a news guy. We know who the news guys are and who the other people are. And that's great. You go over to CNN and you look at Don Lemon. Don Lemon is still characterized as a newsman.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Chris Cuomo was characterized as a newsman. These are not newsmen. These are opinion makers.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And that's why people don't trust the media because if they're going to lie about something as obvious as that, what else are they lying about? All right, here's the book, "Unfreedom of the Press." May 21st. Go out and grab it. There he is, Mark Levin and Mark when I have my big bestselling book out, I expect to be on the radio show.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay?

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: You've got it, buddy. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, thank you. Still ahead, a presidential candidate enters WATTERS' WORLD. Wait until you see who we have in studio. But first, is the PC culture killing the movie industry? We're going to debate it up next.

utterances.speaker: AISHA HASNIE, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Live from "America's News Headquarters," I'm Aishah Hasnie. A shocking new report commissioned by Ohio State University says a team doctor sexually abused male students for more than two decades, and that numerous university officials knew about that abuse, but did the little to stop it. Dr. Richard Strauss, who killed himself in 2005, is accused of abusing at least 177 young men who participated in 16 different sports before retiring from OSU with honors. A former CIA officer convicted of selling military secrets to China was sentenced to 20 years in Federal prison. Prosecutors say Kevin Mallory traveled to Shanghai to meet with a Chinese agent twice in 2017. He was paid $25,000.00. He was also caught on surveillance video scanning classified documents on a digital memory card at the Post Office. He plans to appeal. I'm Aishah Hasnie, back to WATTERS' WORLD.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: People watch movies to laugh and relax and unwind. Many enjoy older films from decades ago which still hold up today. But writing in "The Hill," Christian Toto wonders, will political correctness kill classic movies? The entertainment industry is under the watchful eye of the PC police. Already films like "Gone with the Wind," "16 candles" have come under heavy criticism from social justice advocates and #MeToo activists. What else could wind up on the cutting room floor? Joining me now to discuss, radio talk show host Larry Elder and political columnist, Cathy Areu. All right, let's begin with a classic movie comedy that everybody loves that I'm not so sure would hold up today, "Blazing Saddles," roll it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Okay, so Cathy, we begin with ladies first here. Obviously, Mel Brooks in a Native American outfit, that today would be seen as extremely controversial. How do you feel about that?

utterances.speaker: CATHY AREU, CATALINA MAGAZINE PUBLISHER
utterances.utterance: Unfortunately, yes, extremely controversial. Mel Brooks, funny at the time, but as "schwarz" is black in German, so he's making fun of their skin color. He is not laughing with a minority. He is laughing at a minority and then makes a Nazi joke, "avidazen." Nothing is funny about Nazis, I don't think in this day and age. And no, it does not make it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So Larry, you know, Mel Brooks, obviously, comedy icon responsible for some of the greatest comedy films of all time. But you know, back then -- when was this? 1974? I don't even know if they still really run this on cable any more. Do you see something like this just kind of is falling off the TV screens because people don't want to see it?

utterances.speaker: LARRY ELDER, RADIO TALK SHOW HOST
utterances.utterance: Oh, absolutely. I agree with her. This movie would never be greenlighted right now. And it isn't just that scene regarding the Native American. It's the running jokes about gays, including the use of the F word for gays. There's no way that would be greenlighted right now. And that isn't necessarily a bad thing. I know a couple of gays who saw the movie when it came out and they were offended. Most people weren't at the time, but things have changed. Comedy reflects the change of our culture. Our culture has changed. People have become a lot more sensitive now. So movies like that would never in a million years be greenlighted and that isn't necessarily a bad thing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So let's see. What would this be? Thirteen years after Blazing Saddles, you had "Spaceballs." Everybody remembers "Spaceballs" with Rick Moranis. Let's roll a clip of that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, so obviously, the Afro pick combing the desert. Extremely edgy. I mean, was that edgy at the time? Because right now obviously, you know people would pick up on that or Cathy, could comedians -- they can get away with certain things. I mean, not everything, but certain things. Do you think that they could get away with something like this today?

utterances.speaker: AREU
utterances.utterance: Well, were they laughing with the group that they were representing or at the group? So I don't think Tyler Perry productions would have been informed. It would be the number one movie company with Media Films if they were so happy with these films. So no, I don't think the audiences were laughing along with it. The minorities were not laughing along with this movie.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, okay. Were you Larry?

utterances.speaker: ELDER
utterances.utterance: You know, Jesse, the problem is, again, there's a line between being respectful and being hypersensitive.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: ELDER
utterances.utterance: When, for example, Scarlett Johansson accepts a role of a transgender and then, it gets hammered because she is not transgender, and then rescinds the role, we've got a problem here. We've crossed the line from respectful paying attention to people's feelings to hypersensitivity and I think that's the concern. That's the area that comedians have to focus on and it's hard. It's hard.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right, and it's usually about the comedians and the comedian culture, and the producers are involved, too, but they're the ones that are usually the arbiter of what's appropriate and what's not appropriate and usually, they hit the right mark with the audience although audience obviously they've changed. Let's go to, I guess this would be a #MeToo situation. I don't know how this would fly, "Goldfinger," James Bond, 1964. Check it out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, so man talk and then the slap. Cathy, there's a lot of gratuitous sex and misogyny in movies all the time. This is a little bit different though, I imagine from your perspective.

utterances.speaker: AREU
utterances.utterance: Well, the "James Bond" movies always took advantage of their female characters to be the hourglass figures and to slap them like little pets. So my mother who did not consider herself a feminist actually would not even watch "James Bond" because of these scenes. And she didn't know why, but she was uncomfortable.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But still today, Larry, "James Bond" incredibly popular. The movies are, you know, all over Netflix and everything and the DVDs still sell. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: ELDER
utterances.utterance: Yes, but the "James Bond" of today is very different than the "James Bond" of the 60s and the 70s. You don't find that kind of mad man mentality approach to women anymore. I think Daniel Craig -- last few movies -- he was actually loyal. He wasn't a philanderer. So the whole thing has changed now. You don't have this kind of put down of women routinely in movies anymore and that's a good thing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, that is a good thing. And you know, let the audience decide, if it's a problem. They won't watch it. All right, guys, thank you guys very much. Guys and gals. Excuse me. I want to be PC. Wait until you hear the shocking amount of time people spend gossiping about other people. We're going to gossip about one of our great friends, Greg Gutfeld, right next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We're all guilty of gossiping. I admit, I love spreading juicy rumors about Gutfeld. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I gossip about Greg probably the most.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: To know Greg is to gossip about him. He complains a lot. He says a lot of ridiculous things. I don't think I would say anything behind your back that I wouldn't say to your face.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'd do the same way.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you know that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But the amount of time we spend doing it going to surprise you. A new study finds that we spend 52 minutes each day talking about other people. But it's not always trash talk. In fact, we're negative only 15 percent of the time. And by the way, the study claims that women and men gossip the same. I don't believe that. Joining me now, my co-host on "The Five," and the host of "The Daily Briefing" Dana Perino.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.utterance: My debut in “Watters' World.”

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This is a big deal, Dana, there it is. Everyone is watching, including Greg. I wanted to talk to you about Greg because, you know --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I've known him a long time.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You've known him a lot longer than I have. Have you noticed -- I wouldn't say a development -- have you noticed a change in his personality, recently? Because it seems like things are getting different.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Like he is tense.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He is tenser, but it's going in different directions.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Sometimes, like okay, so this is what I'd say about Greg. There's a lot going on in there. I mean, back in the day, you might have classified him as a genius. I don't know how his family dealt with him.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How far back in the day was that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There's a lot -- right -- he is like, so clever. One of the things that's amazing about him that people might not realize is his mom recognized early on that he had this really creative mind. So when he would be off of school, she let him watch TV all day, he loves TV. We know that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's all he watches.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: She bought him "Mad Magazine."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And he would read that and go, "Oh, these people, they get me." And he -- the story revolves on that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's a total weirdo. But I wanted to ask you about this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's gotten worse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So now, he is doing a few strange things, which I'd like to discuss with, but now he walks home.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: When it's nice out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He walks which is like -- it's like a 50-minute walk. Which is a little strange.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's a good exercise.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I guess, but it's bizarre. I also think he bought a guitar.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We have the guitar. Can we show the guitar? Greg is in a band now? I think a band by himself. There it is. He is playing guitar.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow. He loves that. He is like -- he is just going to sit there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What do you think that's about?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think that it's something that he used to do. Did you know that he used to be in a band and he used to be a singer?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Kind of. Wait, we have a picture of him hanging out with some rock stars. Can we show that? He's got some crazy jacket on. Was it Kiss or was it like -- there it is. There it is.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, I mean, obviously he has interesting taste in music.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Interesting is a generous word.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Most people would say horrific.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He is really particular about what he is going to eat.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, it is all he talks about. So from the back half of the show to the end, all he says is --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, that's like the commercial block after the A block. The commercial is like, "What am I going to eat? When am I going eat?"

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's usually ribs.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, it's ribs. And then he had a bad episode with chicken.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh no more chicken.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Remember he was off for a couple of days.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But he was off for chicken?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well no. There was some sort of food poisoning thing. I don't know what it was, but there has been --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Was that when he hit his head on the door?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, that was another -- no, that was the time. That was actually not his fault. He was walking in to the studio and somebody was walking out at the same time.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. But he claimed he needed a CAT scan.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He did. He got one --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And he was fine.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He takes this very seriously.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry. Yes. He takes it very seriously.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But he did get hurt. The other thing is, he likes to make fun of me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He loves that. I think --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He loves to make fun of little people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I want to say something. I feel like he's been a little tougher on you than usual recently, what do you think that's about?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I don't know. Sometimes I wonder if he hates me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, he doesn't hate you. He loves you. You know who he really loves. Here's things he -- three things he really loves to talk about. Watch.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's called nuclear power. It's the cleanest, safest. What you're seeing -- it's cleaner, safer versions of nuclear power. Other kinds of nuclear power. The problem with opioids is that they work. The abuse of prescription opioids is so low. Let me use a little Scott Adams math on you, okay.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Got it. That was Greg's idea.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: It's the Gutfeld --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That was a Scott Adams idea. I love the sound of you frustrated over my "Animals are Great" video. Yes, animals are great unlike Ed Henry.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You know what? So when "The Five" first started, he and I were seated next to each other not because we knew each other, we didn't. But we're the shortest.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They put two short people, right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: For the lighting, but it turns out, I really think that I was able to do the other things I've done at Fox because of him, because I had been a spokesperson for someone else for so long.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's not kiss his butt too much. I mean, we're here to gossip about him.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Okay, do you remember in Nashville?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I am just saying, he keeps repeating the same stuff.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, but I think --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Nuclear power, Scott Adams, opioids are great, animals are great, animals and opioids apparently.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But see now, see, he has the power of persuasion, I think in his mind because he thinks now everybody knows animals are great. They get it in their head, they associate it with him. But remember in Nashville, the other thing he did?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Remember the commercial break, he leaned over to me and he said, "I look angry all the time."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We need something to help Greg with his anger. Probably wine.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, there's a lot wine.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There's a lot of that. Let's get to that next time. We'll talk about the wine.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I would love to come back --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, we're going to have you back on.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Just to talk about Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Watters -- fine.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There we are. Up next, a presidential candidate enters “Watters' World.” It's not Joe Biden. Someone else, we will show you.

utterances.speaker: VERMIN SUPREME, PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: We plan to try a casino across the southern border which will not repel the invaders, but absorb them as part of my pathway to citizenship through indentured servitude. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Are you serious?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was Vermin Supreme and I at the DNC convention in 2016. Vermin is a perennial candidate for President of the United States with the platform of free ponies for everybody. Vermin's already thrown his hat or boot into the ring this year running as a libertarian, and he joins me now. All right, Mr. Supreme.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: Yes, sir. Hello. Pleasure to be here on your television program. Thank you for having me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, thank you for joining me. Although, we go a long way back.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: I just flew in at the airport, and you'll never guess who I saw.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Who did you see?

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: Mr. Joe Biden. They have him working for the TSA.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: If that's right -- in his wheelhouse.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: Yes. Unfortunately, he fell asleep while he was sniffing my wife's hair.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Sleepy, Joe.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: I'm telling you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You can't do that at TSA though.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: I'm telling you, he can't hardly stay awake.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's true. All right, so you've been running for a very long time since 1987.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: Yes, sir. Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And you have a Political Action Committee, people donate.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: Well, it is a campaign committee if you will. It's a 527.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: It is called Pony Up, America.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, so people donate to you. And then you use that money to travel around.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: The more I can convince people to give me money, verminsupreme.com, the more I can spend, and yes, I've been traveling around the country to appear at various libertarian conventions.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And it's a beautiful country, is it not?

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: It truly is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, so here's why --

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: And it must only be spent on legitimate campaign expenses.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. Like your boot?

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: Yes. That's would be a legitimate campaign expense.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's a legitimate campaign expense.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: If I were to buy a pony, that would be a legitimate campaign.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay, good.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: Yes, it would be.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So I have my opinion that there's so many Democrats running for President because a lot of them just like want to do what you do is raise a lot of money, travel the country in the warm weather, raise their speaking fees, maybe write a book and network around and then when it gets cold, they'll just drop right out.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: Absolutely, sir. I mean, many people run for many different reasons. And of course, selling books and upping your speaking fee and gaining national notoriety is certainly one of those things that people do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And I don't see your platform is that different than a lot of the other candidates. I mean, you had people trimming their nose hairs. You have people like what? Working out at the gym and they're doing all this crazy stuff. I mean, you and the rest of the Democratic field, there's not that big of a difference.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: Oh yes. I've got a preview of a regular guy and you do regular things all the time. I'm just a regular guy doing regular things. I got a haircut once. Look at that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: Yes, sure.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You actually need a little beard trim. You should go in there and like livestream that or something like that.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: I think we will.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: People might like that.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: Well, Beto did that teeth cleaning stunt, obviously referencing to the mandatory tooth brushing law.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you don't like stunts at all?

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: Oh, no, no, because gingivitis has been eroding the gum line of this great nation of ours for long enough and must be stopped. For too long, our country has been suffering a great moral and oral decay in spirit and incisors. Our country's future depends on its ability to bite back. We can no longer be a nation indentured. We must brace ourselves, our very salvation is at stake as we cross the bridge work into the 23rd Century, may we become a sea of shining smiles from sea to shining smiles.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Good luck in 2020.

utterances.speaker: SUPREME
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Don't forget, Vermin Supreme, my new book, "I Pony." My new book.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Up next, "Last Call."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Time now for "Last Call." The NBA Draft this week and the New York Knicks missed out on the number one overall pick, Zion Williamson leaving fans like Stephen A. Smith, really upset.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: We're talking about a box office dude, a potential megastar, a Skywalker and all of this reduced to rubble because Mark Tatum in the NBA office tried to be -- wanted to be honest, and they didn't fix it so the damn -- didn't get the number one overall pick. I cannot believe this. I can't take it. I love you all, but I've got to go. I'm just too offended.
